channel.title: Ars-Technica on Panz3r News
channel.description: Recent content in Ars-Technica on news.panz3r.dev

item.title: After defeating Hernando de Soto, the Chickasaw took his stuff and remade it
item.description: The site offers rare evidence of interactions between de Soto and Indigenous people.

item.title: With Apple Pay Later, Apple may take another stab at the PayPal model
item.description: Apple plans to offer iPhone users another way to borrow money.

item.title: Amazon bought Facebook’s satellite team to help build Starlink competitor
item.description: Amazon’s Project Kuiper got some new employees as Facebook ended satellite project.

item.title: Google tries out error correction on its quantum processor
item.description: Two options for error correction both work, but current hardware limits them.

item.title: iOS zero-day let SolarWinds hackers compromise fully updated iPhones
item.description: Flaw was exploited when government officials clicked on links in LinkedIn messages.

item.title: Microsoft fails to provide Windows 10 VM images for developers
item.description: Microsoft’s Windows 10 VMs for devs expired on July 10. They’re still missing.

item.title: Facebook tries to beat FTC lawsuit by pushing Chair Lina Khan off the case
item.description: Facebook petitions for Khan’s recusal as FTC decides whether to continue lawsuit.

item.title: The $2,000 Super Mario smartwatch you’ve always wanted is here
item.description: Under the Mario theme, this is a dog-slow Wear OS device that will be obsolete soon.

item.title: SpaceX will soon fire up its massive Super Heavy booster for the first time
item.description: What has SpaceX been up to in South Texas since early May?

item.title: Texan city to deploy intelligent traffic system from Velodyne Lidar
item.description: The pilot program will use lidar to monitor traffic at a dangerous intersection.

item.title: Sweeping “Green Deal” promises to revamp EU economy, slash carbon pollution
item.description: Slew of proposals still leaves the hardest cuts for future generations.

item.title: Auto-aim cheatmaker halts development at Activision’s request
item.description: Developer says, “My intent was never to do anything illegal.”

item.title: VW Group’s 10-year plan: A single EV platform across all its brands
item.description: The new platform, due in 2025, will be called SSP.

item.title: Today’s best tech deals: Fire HD Kids tablets, Fitbit trackers, and more
item.description: Dealmaster also has deals on Nest gadgets, pre-owned games, and ANC headphones.

item.title: Review: Skyward Sword HD isn’t the 35th Zelda birthday gift we’d hoped for
item.description: Welcome tweaks for brand-new Switch players, but the same can’t be said for Skyward vets.

item.title: We’re getting a Wheel of Time prequel film trilogy to augment Amazon series
item.description: Films will focus on history of Robert Jordan’s fictional world before events of books.

item.title: SolarWinds 0-day gave Chinese hackers privileged access to customer servers
item.description: Hackers IDed as DEV-0322 have a fondness for defense contractors and software-makers.

item.title: Museum obtains rare demo of id Software’s Super Mario Bros. 3 PC port
item.description: 1990 demo was rejected by Nintendo but led to id’s own Commander Keen.

item.title: Tennessee has gone “anti-vaccine,” state vaccine chief says after being fired
item.description: Vaccine chief says she was fired for noting state’s 34-year-old policy for vaccinating teens.

item.title: How much do you pay your ISP? Consumer Reports wants to see your bill
item.description: Your bill and a speed test can help Consumer Reports analyze Internet prices.

item.title: A Neanderthal carved a geometric design in bone 51,000 years ago
item.description: Here’s more evidence that Neanderthals were as creative and cultured as us.

item.title: Apple introduces MagSafe Battery Pack to charge the iPhone 12 on the go
item.description: It costs $99 and ships this month.

item.title: If we want to look for life on Europa, we’d better bring a drill
item.description: Impacts and radiation ensure any interesting chemicals won’t last at the surface.

item.title: Firefox 89 delivered more speed—today’s Firefox 90 adds SmartBlock 2.0
item.description: Mozilla’s browser continues ramping up its speed and blocking efforts.

item.title: BMW abandons the i3, the car that could have birthed a bright electric future
item.description: BMW’s forsaken i3 was exceptional, underwhelming, and far too ahead of its time.

item.title: AT&T will let unlimited-data customers pay more to avoid the slow lane
item.description: AT�T says users can soon “stay in the fast lane” on its priciest unlimited plan.

item.title: Russia’s space chief wishes his oligarchs invested in space like Branson and Musk
item.description: Dmitry Rogozin called the Virgin Galactic flight a “landmark.”

item.title: Google Meet puts the clamps on free users, imposes 1-hour meeting limit
item.description: Google’s pandemic promo let free users video chat for 24 hours, but now it’s over.

item.title: Google tries to attract Stadia publishers with better revenue sharing
item.description: Platform will take 15 percent cut on first $3 million in sales for new titles.

item.title: Is our machine learning? Ars takes a dip into artificial intelligence
item.description: In the first part of a new series, we look at matching the problem to the tool.

item.title: Our brains “read” expressions of illusory faces in things just like real faces
item.description: “For the brain, fake or real, faces are all processed the same way.”

item.title: Better performance for pirates: Crack removes stutters from Capcom PC game
item.description: This time, Denuvo doesn’t appear to be the culprit… entirely.

item.title: F1 2021 reviewed: Codemasters adds story, keeps the racing sim feeling fresh
item.description: Get ready for the return of Devon Butler, the most hated man in racing.

item.title: Startup hopes the world is ready to buy quantum processors
item.description: Quantum processors are mostly used via cloud services; QuantWare will ship you one.

item.title: Google’s new Drive app replaces Backup and Sync with Drive File Stream
item.description: The new Drive desktop app is available for Windows and Mac only.

item.title: Health officials rail against Pfizer’s push for COVID boosters—for many reasons
item.description: “What part of ‘this is a global crisis’ are we not getting?”

item.title: The best version of FIFA 22 won’t be on PC
item.description: PC and last-gen consoles lack machine-learning-powered “HyperMotion” animations.

item.title: Maybe not so fast with the phage therapy?
item.description: Even though viruses attack harmful bacteria, the immune system attacks viruses.

item.title: FCC speed standard that Ajit Pai never updated is too slow, GAO report says
item.description: FCC raised its standard to 25/3Mbps in 2015 and hasn’t changed it since.

item.title: Microsoft discovers critical SolarWinds zero-day under active attack
item.description: Flaws allow attackers to run malicious code on machines hosting Serv-U products.

item.title: Bone-conduction headphones: Long-term test and review of AfterShokz
item.description: After four months of testing, we love these for podcasts—not so much for music.

item.title: Android 12 will default to a play-as-you-download scheme for newer games
item.description: No developer support needed: Android 12 will do “play-as-you-download” automatically.

item.title: $11 billion in 9 days—Texas’ natural gas sellers cashed in on deep freeze
item.description: State’s gas supplies halved during cold snap, but sellers made record profits.

item.title: Here’s why Richard Branson’s flight matters—and, yes, it really matters
item.description: “I absolutely believe this is that moment."

item.title: World record for most expensive video game auction is now $1.56 million [Updated]
item.description: Beats the price set by a rare Legend of Zelda copy, which only lasted 48 hours.

item.title: Archaeologists “flabbergasted” to find Cerne Giant’s origins are medieval
item.description: “Everyone was wrong, and that makes these results even more exciting.”

item.title: How much shipping can we get through a warming Arctic?
item.description: Research discusses the logistic, social, and ecological impacts of a warm Arctic.

item.title: Creepypasta and the search for the ghost in the machine
item.description: Stories of haunted video games have circulated for decades.

item.title: The weekend’s best tech deals: Nintendo Switch Lite, MacBook Air, and more
item.description: Dealmaster also has deals on Dell monitors, good board games, and portable SSDs.

item.title: When science breaks bad: A rogues’ gallery of history’s worst scientists
item.description: A new book catalogs some of the greatest ethical lapses done in the name of science.

item.title: Quest for “green” cement draws big name investors to $300B industry
item.description: Startups and venture capitalists are joining concrete makers against a hard problem.
